title: Webnovela for Hispanic Dementia Family Caregivers
description_brief: Photozig and Stanford University are creating a new program for Hispanic dementia caregivers to help cope with caregiving, alleviate related stress, and enhance quality of life for caregivers, with funding from the National Institute on Aging. The program includes a new education online telenovela (Webnovela), online resources, handouts and a DVD (for users without Internet) on how to deal with caregiving stress and handle difficult situations.
description_detailed:
The goal of Webnovela program is to evaluate and develop materials for helping caregivers to cope with caregiving, alleviate related distress, and improve their quality of life.

The investigators are evaluating different materials, which may provide caregiving strategies, practical tips and help to enhance caregivers' skills to deal with demanding tasks of caregiving, alleviate related stress, and improve quality of life.

Research Program Steps:

1. Caregivers will be asked some simple questions about themselves and their family members to see if they are eligible for the project (fill out Enrollment Form and Informed Consent).
2. A Program survey will be sent, which can be completed online, or returned in a pre-mailed envelope.
3. Participants will receive links to online resources, related materials and instructions. The investigators ask participants to access the online resources, read provided brochures and guides, and follow the instructions. Materials are expected to help participants in their caregiver role.
4. After completing the program, the second and final survey should be filled out online or returned by pre-mailed envelope.

groups.title: Webnovela
groups.description:
Caregivers will watch the Webnovela and read related information. The Webnovela is a short online Telenovela in Spanish, specifically designed for Hispanic caregivers on how to cope with dementia caregiving. A DVD will be available to participants without Internet access.

Webnovela

groups.title: Control
groups.description:
Caregivers will be directed to existing web sites, such as NIA Alzheimer's and Dementia Resources in Spanish. Participants will receive related materials in Spanish language.

Information

outcomeMeasures.title: Stress on the Perceived Stress Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: The "Perceived Stress Scale" measures the overall level of stress. This instrument contains 10 items accessing overall appraisals of stress in the past month. Minimum score (best value)=0. Maximum score (worst value)=40. Higher values represent a worse outcome.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: One (1) subject in the Webnovela group and one (1) subject in the Control group completed the study, but they did not have full data related to the Primary Outcome "Stress on the Perceived Stress Scale." These subjects were not included in this data analysis.

groups.title: Webnovela

Information

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Burden on the Revised Memory and Behavior Problems Checklist
outcomeMeasures.description: This scale measures the type/number of dementia patients disturbing behaviors, and how much they bother caregivers with 24 items describing possible troublesome behaviors that the patient might evidence in the past month. Caregivers are first asked whether the dementia patient had displayed any of these in the time period, and secondly to rate on a 5-point scale (0=not at all; 4= extremely) how much this "bothered or upset" them. A "conditional bother" score is calculated which is the "upset" or "bother" ratings for only the problematic behavior that occurred. The scale refers to the caregiver. Minimum score (best value)=0. Maximum score (worst value)=4. Higher values represent a worse outcome.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Two (2) subjects in the Webnovela group completed the study, but they did not have full data related to the Secondary Outcome "Caregiver Burden on the Revised Memory and Behavior Problems Checklist." These subjects were not included in this data analysis.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described is an educational/behavioral program (an online telenovela "Webnovela", online resources, handouts and a DVD) aimed at helping Hispanic dementia caregivers cope with stress and improve quality of life — not a drug or biologic. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Act: Key extracted details — Photozig and Stanford University developed the Webnovela (Mirela) for Hispanic/Latino dementia caregivers; it is a behavioral/supportive intervention funded by the National Institute on Aging. citeturn0search0turn0search9

Act (evidence of effectiveness): A pilot study of the Webnovela Mirela reported significant reductions in caregiver stress and depressive symptoms, supporting its role as a psychosocial/caregiver support intervention rather than a pharmacologic treatment. citeturn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — This trial tests a supportive behavioral intervention (caregiver education/stress management). Per the category definitions, it does not involve biologics or small molecules targeting Alzheimer pathology, nor a cognitive enhancer or a treatment for neuropsychiatric symptoms in patients. Therefore it does not fit any of the four therapeutic categories and should be classified as 'N/A'. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Web search results / sources (selected): Photozig project page describing the Mirela Webnovela and NIA award. citeturn0search0; PubMed abstract reporting the pilot study outcomes for Webnovela Mirela. citeturn0search1; Clinical-trials registry entry for "Webnovela for Hispanic Dementia Family Caregivers" (NCT02489110) with intervention details and objectives. citeturn0search2; Trial listings summarizing arms and measures (MedPath / trial mirrors). citeturn0search3; Veeva/clinical mirror with design and recruitment details. citeturn0search8
